comments.author: muzixing
comments.body:
[6. ](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-cats-framework-10#section-6)[Security Considerations](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-cats-framework-10#name-security-considerations)
The computing resource information changes over time very frequently, especially with the creation and termination of service instances. When such information is carried in a routing protocol, too many updates may affect network stability. This issue could be exploited by an attacker (e.g., by spawning and deleting service contact instances very rapidly). CATS solutions must support guards against such misbehaviors. For example, these solutions should support aggregation techniques, dampening mechanisms, and threshold-triggered distribution updates.

The information distributed by the C-SMAs and C-NMAs may be sensitive. Such information could indeed disclose intelligence about the network and the location of compute resources hosted in service sites. This information may be used by an attacker to identify weak spots in an operator's network. Furthermore, such information may be modified by an attacker resulting in disrupted service delivery for the clients, even including misdirection of traffic to an attacker's service implementation. CATS solutions must support authentication and integrity-protection mechanisms between C-SMAs/C-NMAs and C-PSes, and between C-PSes and Ingress CATS-Forwarders. Also, C-SMA agents need to support a mechanism to authenticate the services for which they provide information to C-PS computation logics, among other CATS functions.

The above text is the security consideration in CATS framework draft. it covers the intergrity-protection, the routes dampening mechanisms. Do you have any thoughts on the text? I may try to add more in these days, but would like to know your idea before doing that.

A client-facing service function instance that is responsible for receiving requests in the context of a given service. The same service contact instance may dispatch service requests to one or more service instances (e.g., ***a service contact instance*** that behaves as a service load-balancer).
.

issues.title: Zongpeng： Some proposal for policy delivery
issues.author: muzixing
issues.body:
Hi， Cheng

    We have prepared some context for a new section in the framework document.


    Welcome for comments.


4.6.  Policy Delivery

As shown in Figure1, the control plane and management plane need to communicate some policies to the data plane. The control plane and management plane can be implemented in a control center entity.

If the C-PS is logically centralized, it needs to communicate some policies to the CATS-Forwarders. In this case, the network entity containing the C-PS, such as a control center, should be able to perform management and/or control functions, including computing information awareness function, service scheduling function, etc. It collects computing and network information, and schedules service based on computing and network information. The CATS-Forwarders performs data plane functions or routing functions.

If the C-PS is collocated with an Ingress CATS-Forwarder, the functions that the Ingress CATS-Forwarder supports would include computing information awareness function, service scheduling function and data forwarding function. In this case, Ingress CATS-Forwarders make forwarding decisions for a given service request that has been received from a client according to the capabilities and status information of both service instances and network.

In either case, management plane policies need to be delivered to the CATS-Forwarders. For example, a general scheduling policy can be sent to the Ingress CATS-Forwarder, which would include policy execution node information, topology information and configuration information for real-time state collection of resources. If the C-PS is collocated with an Ingress CATS-Forwarder, the policy execution node would be the Ingress CATS-Forwarder. The topology information could be the nodes that need to be communicated to obtain the computing information. According to the topology information and configuration information in the received general scheduling policy, the Ingress CATS-Forwarder obtains the real-time status information of the computing resource, the service resource or the network resource. Based on these resource state information and the scheduling policy information in the general scheduling policy, the ingress CATS-Forwarder can obtain the target scheduling policy for the service requirement and schedule the corresponding service's traffic.



Best Regards
Zongpeng Du

pulls.title: Terminology section: grammar edits, minor term edits leveraging existing RFCs.
pulls.author: taylorpaul
pulls.body:
The preponderance of this merge requests consists of grammatical edits to improve clarity, conciseness and avoid passive voice (by stating the actor) where possible. 

Here are the changes that may warrant discussion on the mailing list: 

**1. Updated the client definition:**
- OLD: An endpoint that is connected to a service provider network.
- NEW: An endpoint that requests service from a service provider network.
- DISCUSSION: A device connected to a network is a host, what makes it a client IMHO is the fact it enters into a client-server relationship by initiating a service request.

**2. Update the flow definition:**
- OLD: A flow is identified by the 5-tuple transport coordinates (source address and destination address, source and destination port numbers, and protocol).
- NEW: "A set of IP packets passing an Observation Point in the network during a certain time interval. All packets that belong to a particular Flow have a set of common properties derived from the data contained in the packet and from the packet treatment at the Observation Point." {{?RFC3954}}. Typically CATS components identify flows by the 5-tuple transport coordinates (source address and destination address, source and destination port numbers, and protocol).
- DISCUSSION: I think the OLD version only identified a flow without defining it. If we want to not quote so much text we could simply state see RFC3954 but I think that gets annoying for new readers pretty quickly.

**3. Update the metric definition:**
- OLD: A piece of information that provides suitable input to a selection mechanism to determine a CATS egress node.
-NEW: A quantitative measure that provides suitable input to a selection mechanism for CATS decision making.
- DISCUSSION: More specific than piece of information -> "quantitative measure" see similar in [rfc8911:Registry for Performance Metrics](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc8911/ ). Specifically, the terminology for "Performance Metric"

**4. Update the service definition:**
- OLD:  An offering that is made available by a service provider by orchestrating a set of resources (networking, compute, storage, etc.).
-NEW: An interface a service provider exposes to a client to perform a function. Service providers establish services by orchestrating a set of resources (networking, compute, storage, etc.).
- DISCUSSION: I referenced the service definition here to guide this definition update: [RFC8309](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8309#section-2). I think interface to provide a function remains general enough but is more specific than "an offering".

**5. Update the service request definition:**
- OLD:
 : A request to access or invoke a specific service. Such a request is steered to a service contact instance via CATS-Forwarders.
 : A service request is placed using service-specific protocols.
 : Service requests are not explicitly sent by clients to CATS-Forwarders.

- NEW:
 : A request to access or invoke a specific service. CATS-Forwarders steer a service request to a service contact instance.
 : Clients must place a service request using service-specific protocols.
 : Clients direct service requests to a CS-ID without explicit knowledge of CATS-Forwarders.
 - DISCUSSION: I was not sure about what the original authors intended about the third bullet relating to "explicitly sent". I bring to the groups attention to ensure I did not change the original meaning in my edits.
